STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 26, 2024
Susan Joy Mitchell
SAMARITAS - SOUTHWEST
4341 S WESTNEDGE AVE STE 2000, Suite 2000
KALAMAZOO, MI, 49008-3284
RE: License#: CB390258392
Dear Susan Joy Mitchell:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 4/19/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB390258392
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas
Licensee Designee: Laura Louise Mitchell Pflug
Chief Administrator: Susan Joy Mitchell
Name of Agency: SAMARITAS - SOUTHWEST
Agency Address: 4341 S WESTNEDGE AVE STE 2000
Suite 2000
KALAMAZOO, MI 49008-3284
Agency Telephone #: 2693455776
Original Issuance Date: 12/09/2003
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (b) Verification that the foster parent is
willing to accept the foster child.
Four of Eight Borrowed Bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of foster
parent willingness to accept the placement prior to the placement date.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (f) Documentation that the foster parent
has received orientation to the policies of
the borrowing agency.

Three of Eight Borrowed Bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of
foster parent orientation to borrowing agency policies and procedures prior to the
placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/22/2022, CAP Approved 5/4/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (g) A copy of the foster parent /agency
agreement signed by the foster parent
and the borrowing agency.
Five of Eight Borrowed Bed files reviewed did not contain signed foster
parent/agency agreements prior to the placement.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
One of Eleven open youth files reviewed (Eight foster care & Three IL) contained
an initial service plan that was completed late by two days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/22/2022, CAP Approved 5/4/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:

• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of Eleven open youth files reviewed (Eight foster care & Three IL) contained
updated service plans that were not completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/22/2022, CAP Approved 5/4/2022.
Interim 4/26/2023, CAP Approved 5/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (6) Service plans must be signed by the social
services worker and the social services
supervisor.
One of Eleven open youth files reviewed (Eight foster care & Three IL) was
missing the supervisor and worker signatures on one USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 4/26/2023, CAP Approved 5/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans
• (2) If parental rights have not been terminated,
the service plan must include all the following:
• (e) Documentation of how the parents
were informed of their rights and
responsibilities in the care of their child.
One of Eleven open youth files reviewed (Eight foster care & Three IL) was
missing documentation that the parents were informed of their rights and
responsibilities in the ISP. This is typically documented on the DHS 5307 and
within social work contacts which then populate into the ISP.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited under FOM 722-06J)
Renewal 4/22/2022, CAP Approved 5/4/2022.
Special Investigation 2022C0112021 dated 10/6/2022, CAP Approved
11/16/2022

F OM 722-06B F AMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement
or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.
Ten of Eleven open youth files reviewed (Eight foster care & Three IL) were
either missing documentation of required FTMs being held or were missing the
signed documents required after an FTM. Twelve of the missing/overdue FTMs
were related to service plan development within thirty days of the service plan
due date, and two were missing for placement preservation/change. Additionally,
six FTMs that were documented to have been held did not have the required
signed paperwork uploaded.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/22/2022, CAP Approved 5/4/2022.
Interim 4/26/2023, CAP Approved 5/11/2023.
Special Investigation 2022C0112021 dated 10/6/2022, CAP Approved
11/16/2022

F OM 722-06H C ASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face
contact in the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If
there is more than one caregiver, such as a primary
and secondary caregiver, the caseworker must have a
face-to-face contact with the secondary caregiver in the
home at least once each quarter.
One of Eight files of youth in foster care placements reviewed did not contain
documentation that the secondary caregiver was present in the foster home for
required visitation at least quarterly.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 4/26/2023, CAP Approved 5/11/2023.
FOM-722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
S IGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care
are placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan to review, and I will have the opportunity to
express my disagreement with the Case

Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report
date.
Eleven of Eleven open youth files reviewed (Eight foster care & Three IL) were
either missing required signatures, had signatures obtained past the required
timeframe, or did not contain documentation of efforts to obtain the required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 4/22/2022, CAP Approved 5/4/2022.
Interim 4/26/2023, CAP Approved 5/11/2023.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Date & method of SE initiation must be the date the SE was initiated by agency
licensing staff and not the date DHHS staff initiated their investigation.
• If an individual is unable to be interviewed by the licensing worker, there must be
an explanation within the report and not just within social work contact as those
do not populate into the report.
• Licensing staff should only be using interviews conducted by other individuals
such as DHHS staff or law enforcement if the licensing worker is unable to
interview the person themselves. If the licensing worker must use notes from
another investigator's interview, the reasons for doing so must be documented
within the report.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Review of where to upload documentation would be beneficial as some
documentation is being uploaded incorrectly.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The one special evaluation reviewed resulting in a violation related to corporal
punishment was reviewed. The foster parent was found in violation after admitting to
using corporal punishment with a youth. An appropriate corrective action plan was
implemented as a result. Concerns with the special evaluation report are documented
within the technical assistance section of this licensing inspection report.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The one CAP submitted by the agency during the period under review was in
response to the 2023 licensing interim inspection report completed on 4/26/2023.
The CAP was approved on 5/11/2023 and addressed nine violations, five of which
were repeated this year. Of those five, the individual incidents of non-compliance
increased in the area of PATP signatures, decreased in the areas of USP
signatures, and remained nearly the same related to service plan timeliness,
FTMs, and case contacts. It is noted that the majority of violations established are
located within one file that was case managed by a worker and supervisor who are
no longer with the agency. Additional corrective action planning will be needed to
address the repeats as well as newly established violations.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
identified barriers to compliance throughout the past year being high staff turnover,
including staff members who left with little or no notice. This included members of
the supervision team. The turnover resulted in difficulty in maintaining consistency
as there was a need to continually train new staff.
Financial Overview
A review of the agency budget as well as an independent auditor's report on the
audit of the agency's consolidated financial statements was reviewed. No
concerns were identified.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed reported currently feeling supported by the supervision team
who they feel is knowledgeable. The staff who have been with the agency for
longer than a year report that the turnover with supervision and workers has been
difficult at time because job responsibilities have had to shift and caseloads must
be reassigned.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has sufficient space and equipment to perform job functions related to
foster care, licensing, and independent living services. Files are stored securely

and physical CHRI is stored in a location that is only accessible to the licensing
Program Manager. A cross shredder is also located within the licensing Program
Manager's office.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
April 25, 2024
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 26, 2024
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
